texts.shortText: Previously misidentified as the European species, Tritonia nilsodhneri, Duvaucelia sp., whipfan nudibranch.

A small to medium-sized cladobranch, peach- to pale-coloured. The rhinophores have a central crown of papillae surrounding a longer single stalk. The rhinophoral sheaths are flared at the rims. The notum is covered with paler, opaque low tubercles of varying sizes. There are also several paired secondary gills on the notum.

Global: Likely endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay, 2â€“36 m in depth.
This species is usually found on reefs, almost always on the Whip fan Eunicella albicans, but occasionally also on other sea fans.
The species preys on the Whip fan, Eunicella albicans.
This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a wavy, narrow peach-coloured spiral coil laid around the prey sea fan.
This species can be confused with the Purple soft coral lacedragon, Marionia sp.7, but is distinguished by its low tubercles.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 214).

Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 107).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 456, 788).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 144).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 71).
